MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ergot Compensation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if his Department will pay compensation to a farmer (name supplied) in County Meath whose cows have become infected with ergot; or whether this farmer will qualify for any low-interest loans on the ground that ergot is a rare disease which farmers are not aware of and are unable to recognise in rye grass.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: My Department do not operate any scheme of compensation or loans at a subsidised interest rate which would cover a case of this kind. The herdowner should be advised to get in touch with the Agricultural Credit Corporation Ltd. to ascertain whether he would qualify for any of the facilities which they offer.

Would the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that this is a very rare disease and one that the Department have never notified farmers in the public Press to be aware of? In view of the hardship on this farmer, losing ten cattle from his herd, would the Minister consider giving a grant or a low-interest loan so as to help him over this difficult period?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Fortunately ergot is a rare disease, possibly so rare that it is not scheduled to be dealt with under the Diseases of Animals Act. It is unfortunate that this man's herd was affected and the only suggestion that could be made is that he should try to get help from the ACC.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I have sympathy for a farmer like that, but possibly sympathy is not much good in such a case. The Department cannot help him, due to the regulations laid down governing the utilisation of Departmental funds.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The remaining questions will appear on next Tuesday's Order Paper, except for those replies which Deputies may wish to collect at the General Office.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Secondhand Diesel Landrovers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will allow the importation of secondhand diesel landrovers as agricultural machinery.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: While I have discretion, under the Motor Vehicles (Registration of Importers) Act, 1968, which regulates the importation of new and used motor vehicles, to authorise the importation of a motor vehicle by a non-registered person, the grant of such facilities is confined to special cases. These are normally cases involving permanent change of residence. As the Act was introduced to protect the motor vehicle assembly industry I would not be prepared to exercise my discretion by extending such facilities to allow the importation of used diesel landrovers by non-registered persons.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disability Benefit Payment.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare why disability benefit has not been paid to a person in County Laois (name supplied) who has been awaiting payment for nine weeks and who is fully qualified.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The person referred to by the Deputy was not qualified for payment of disability benefit on his Irish insurance record at the date of his claim. As he had also worked in England inquiries were made to the British Ministry of Health and Social Security regarding his insurance contributions there so as to determine if these contributions would qualify him on his claim. Details of his British insurance which qualified him for benefit were received in my Department on 24th October, 1974, and payment of the amount of disability benefit due on the medical certificates received was issued to him on 25th October, 1974.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Shortage of Textbooks.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that there is a shortage of some text books for secondary schools; and if he will arrange to have sufficient text books printed each year to meet the students' requirements.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard Burke
Speaker.P: Representations have not been made to my Department that there is a general shortage of text books, although it may happen that there may be a temporary shortage in the case of individual text books due to publishing delays.

School text books are provided through the activities of the various private commercial publishing companies. In the case of prescribed text material close liaison exists between my Department and the publishers so as to ensure an adequate and timely supply of text books. With regard to non-prescribed material teachers are free to choose from a wide range of publications. This freedom of choice is essential both for teacher and pupil. Therefore, any general control or direction regarding the production of text books would be undesirable.
